abstracts.cdata!:
In the light of the prevailing country
            practices and conditions and with the objective of aligning
            better with the country systems, there will be an extension
            of the timeline of the submission of the audits in the India
            portfolio from six to nine months for all active projects,
            starting with audit report due for FY2015. All future
            projects will continue to use the flexibility provided by
            OP/BO 10.00 in terms of determining the timing of the audit.
            This proposal to extend the date of submission of annual
            audit reports to nine months across the active India
            portfolio is being processed in response to India’s request
            dated 21-January-2015.

repnme.cdata!: India - Second Phase of the Hydrology Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Phase of the
            Hydrology Project for India were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            negligible to low, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: for technically
            innovative and institutionally complex projects such as the
            establishment of hydrological information system (HIS)
            across India, a long-term programmatic and demand driven
            approach is required, allowing each implementing agency (IA)
            to progress at its own pace and evolving needs. Central
            agencies need to take a spearheading role regarding HIS data
            exchange and dissemination, in order to accelerate the
            present paradigm shift towards river basin planning and
            integrated water resources management (IWRM) in India.
            Integration of state surface water (SW) and ground water
            (GW) departments and (particularly) state data centers
            facilitates and promotes the integration of SW and GW data
            analyses, enables the adoption of an IWRM approach at state
            level, and improves joint project management and
            implementation. Web-based data processing and storage
            systems facilitate easy accessibility across the country,
            central annual maintenance contract (AMC) and help desk
            functions, and reduce potential future licensing issues.
            Management information system (MIS) systems for projects of
            the nature of HIS - which cannot be subjected to a classic
            economic and financial analysis - need to implement
            data-related value-addition studies as part of the
            monitoring and evaluation and learning (M and E and L)
            environment, by developing a benefit assessment mechanism
            for HIS-related activities.
